clusters.title: Israel strikes Gaza after Netanyahu accuses Hamas of breaching ceasefire
clusters.neutral_headline: Israel Strikes Gaza After Accusations of Ceasefire Violations

items.title: Israel strikes Gaza after Netanyahu accuses Hamas of breaching ceasefire
items.standfirst: Prime minister accuses Hamas of ‘clear violation’ of truce as far-right ministers clamour to resume warIsraeli warplanes struck Gaza on Tuesday night, shortly after Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, ordered the military to carry out “powerful strikes” in Gaza, in the most serious test of the increasingly shaky US-brokered ceasefire.Witnesses reported seeing Israeli planes launch strikes on Gaza City, as well as explosions across the strip shortly after Netanyahu’s announcement. At least seven people were killed in separate strikes in Gaza City and Khan Younis, including two children, medical sources said. Continue reading...
items.content: Prime minister accuses Hamas of ‘clear violation’ of truce as far-right ministers clamour to resume warIsraeli warplanes struck Gaza on Tuesday night, shortly after Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, ordered the military to carry out “powerful strikes” in Gaza, in the most serious test of the increasingly shaky US-brokered ceasefire.Witnesses reported seeing Israeli planes launch strikes on Gaza City, as well as explosions across the strip shortly after Netanyahu’s announcement. At least seven people were killed in separate strikes in Gaza City and Khan Younis, including two children, medical sources said. Continue reading...

items.content: Hamas denies it was behind an attack on Israeli forces inside an area of Gaza under their control and condemns the strikes.

items.title: New Israeli strikes on Gaza threaten fragile ceasefire
items.standfirst: Footage shows emergency crews rescuing civilians from rubble after Israel carried out new strikes across Gaza City.
items.content: Footage shows emergency crews rescuing civilians from rubble after Israel carried out new strikes across Gaza City.

items.title: Israeli planes strike Gaza City after Netanyahu orders 'powerful attacks'
items.standfirst: Israeli planes launched strikes on Gaza City on Tuesday after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu accused the militant group Hamas of violating a ceasefire in the Palestinian territory and ordered the military to carry out "powerful attacks". The Israeli strikes targeted an area close to Shifa hospital, the largest operational hospital in northern Gaza, witnesses and Hamas media said. There was no word yet on any casualties.
items.content: Israeli planes launched strikes on Gaza City on Tuesday after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu accused the militant group Hamas of violating a ceasefire in the Palestinian territory and ordered the military to carry out "powerful attacks". The Israeli strikes targeted an area close to Shifa hospital, the largest operational hospital in northern Gaza, witnesses and Hamas media said. There was no word yet on any casualties.

items.title: Israel launches renewed strikes in Gaza less than 3 weeks into Trump's ceasefire deal
items.standfirst: Israel's military has begun striking the Gaza Strip again, as Israel and Hamas traded blame for violating the ceasefire brokered by President Trump.
items.content: Israel's military has begun striking the Gaza Strip again, as Israel and Hamas traded blame for violating the ceasefire brokered by President Trump.(Image credit: Bashar Taleb)

items.title: Israel carries out airstrikes in Gaza, casting doubt on fragile ceasefire
items.standfirst: The Israeli military carried out airstrikes in the Gaza Strip on Tuesday, according to local health officials, throwing the fragile U.S.-brokered ceasefire between Israel and Hamas into question
items.content: The Israeli military carried out airstrikes in the Gaza Strip on Tuesday, according to local health officials, throwing the fragile U.S.-brokered ceasefire between Israel and Hamas into question

items.title: Israel launches air strikes on Gaza after accusing Hamas of violating ceasefire
items.standfirst: Israeli air strikes killed at least eleven people and wounded four in Gaza City on Tuesday. This comes as Tel Aviv accused Hamas of ceasefire violations by carrying out an attack against Israeli forces. Hamas said in a statement that it remained committed to the truce in the enclave.
items.content: Israeli air strikes killed at least eleven people and wounded four in Gaza City on Tuesday. This comes as Tel Aviv accused Hamas of ceasefire violations by carrying out an attack against Israeli forces. Hamas said in a statement that it remained committed to the truce in the enclave.

items.title: Blasts reported after Netanyahu orders Israeli military to carry out 'powerful' strikes in Gaza
items.standfirst: Blasts have been reported in Gaza after Israel's prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu ordered his military to carry out "powerful" air strikes.
items.content: Blasts have been reported in Gaza after Israel's prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu ordered his military to carry out "powerful" air strikes.

ai_summary: Israel launched airstrikes on Gaza after accusing Hamas of violating a ceasefire agreement.
Hamas denied responsibility for an attack on Israeli forces in a controlled area.
Israeli strikes targeted Gaza City, resulting in multiple casualties, including children.
The United States was notified of the strikes after they had already occurred.
The strikes occurred shortly after Prime Minister Netanyahu ordered "powerful strikes" in Gaza.

clusters.title: Hurricane Melissa makes landfall in Jamaica as Category 5 storm
clusters.neutral_headline: Hurricane Melissa Makes Landfall in Jamaica

items.title: Hurricane Melissa makes landfall in Jamaica as Category 5 storm
items.standfirst: Hurricane Melissa made landfall Tuesday in Jamaica as a fearsome Category 5 storm. Forecasters said it could be the island's "storm of the century."
items.content: Hurricane Melissa made landfall Tuesday in Jamaica as a fearsome Category 5 storm. Forecasters said it could be the island's "storm of the century."

items.title: How climate change impacts larger hurricanes like Melissa
items.standfirst: Hurricane Melissa made landfall in Jamaica on Tuesday as the strongest storm to ever hit the Caribbean country. CBS News' Jason Allen has more on the storm and David Schechter reports on the influence of climate change on larger hurricanes.
items.content: Hurricane Melissa made landfall in Jamaica on Tuesday as the strongest storm to ever hit the Caribbean country. CBS News' Jason Allen has more on the storm and David Schechter reports on the influence of climate change on larger hurricanes.

items.title: 10/28: CBS Mornings Plus
items.standfirst: Jamaica braces for Hurricane Melissa. Also, what to know about Trump’s proposal to import more Argentine beef.
items.content: Jamaica braces for Hurricane Melissa. Also, what to know about Trump’s proposal to import more Argentine beef.

items.title: Hurricane Melissa reportedly ripping roofs off buildings, causing widespread flooding in Jamaica
items.standfirst: Hurricane Melissa is the strongest storm to hit Jamaica in its history. CBS News correspondent Jason Allen reports on the storm from Portmore, Jamaica.
items.content: Hurricane Melissa is the strongest storm to hit Jamaica in its history. CBS News correspondent Jason Allen reports on the storm from Portmore, Jamaica.

items.title: Hurricane Melissa is slamming Jamaica with record strength. Maps show its forecast path.
items.standfirst: Hurricane Melissa made landfall Tuesday in Jamaica as a Category 5 storm and is expected to bring "catastrophic winds, flash flooding and storm surge," forecasters say.
items.content: Hurricane Melissa made landfall Tuesday in Jamaica as a Category 5 storm and is expected to bring "catastrophic winds, flash flooding and storm surge," forecasters say.

items.title: Hurricane Melissa downgraded to Category 4 as it moves over Jamaica
items.standfirst: The National Hurricane Center has downgraded Hurricane Melissa to a Category 4 storm after it made landfall in Jamaica on Tuesday afternoon as a Category 5. CBS News meteorologist Zoe Mintz has the latest.
items.content: The National Hurricane Center has downgraded Hurricane Melissa to a Category 4 storm after it made landfall in Jamaica on Tuesday afternoon as a Category 5. CBS News meteorologist Zoe Mintz has the latest.

items.title: 'Nervous' British tourists tell of Hurricane Melissa ordeal
items.standfirst: Up to 8,000 holidaying British citizens are in Jamaica as it is battered by one of the strongest Atlantic hurricanes in history.
items.content: Up to 8,000 holidaying British citizens are in Jamaica as it is battered by one of the strongest Atlantic hurricanes in history.

items.title: 3 things to know about Hurricane Melissa
items.standfirst: Melissa was a Category 5 hurricane, the highest level, when it made landfall Tuesday in Jamaica.
items.content: Melissa was a Category 5 hurricane, the highest level, when it made landfall Tuesday in Jamaica.

items.title: ‘Storm of the century’: record-breaking Hurricane Melissa hits Jamaica
items.standfirst: Government says it has done all it can to prepare for strongest hurricane in country since records beganHurricane Melissa – latest updatesHurricane Melissa has made landfall in Jamaica, where sheltering residents braced themselves against ferocious winds, heavy flood waters and landslides from the category 5 storm, one of the strongest Atlantic hurricanes in history.Videos and photographs published by local newspapers painted a devastating portrait of the impact: roads transformed into raging rivers, downed power lines and trees, and roofs ripped off buildings by the power of the winds. “Hurricane Melissa is wreaking absolute havoc on Jamaica’s breadbasket parish,” the Jamaica Observer reported from St Elizabeth in the south-west of the island. Continue reading...
items.content: Government says it has done all it can to prepare for strongest hurricane in country since records beganHurricane Melissa – latest updatesHurricane Melissa has made landfall in Jamaica, where sheltering residents braced themselves against ferocious winds, heavy flood waters and landslides from the category 5 storm, one of the strongest Atlantic hurricanes in history.Videos and photographs published by local newspapers painted a devastating portrait of the impact: roads transformed into raging rivers, downed power lines and trees, and roofs ripped off buildings by the power of the winds. “Hurricane Melissa is wreaking absolute havoc on Jamaica’s breadbasket parish,” the Jamaica Observer reported from St Elizabeth in the south-west of the island. Continue reading...

items.title: Strong winds and flying debris as Hurricane Melissa makes landfall
items.standfirst: Storm surges of 13 feet (3.9m) above ground level and destructive waves are expected as the storm hits Jamaica.
items.content: Storm surges of 13 feet (3.9m) above ground level and destructive waves are expected as the storm hits Jamaica.

items.title: Category 5 Hurricane Melissa brings flooding and catastrophic winds to Jamaica
items.standfirst: The Caribbean storm — among the most powerful in history, with 185 mph winds — is expected to bring flash-flooding and landslides as it slowly moves across the island and heads north toward Cuba.
items.content: The Caribbean storm — among the most powerful in history, with 185 mph winds — is expected to bring flash-flooding and landslides as it slowly moves across the island and heads north toward Cuba.(Image credit: Matias Delacroix)

items.title: Jamaica braces for historic storm as Hurricane Melissa makes landfall
items.standfirst: Hurricane Melissa made landfall on Tuesday in Jamaica as a catastrophic Category 5 storm, one of the strongest Atlantic hurricanes in history. Authorities urged people to seek shelter and stay indoors as a storm surge of up to 4 metres and wind speeds of 295 kph were expected across southern Jamaica.
items.content: Hurricane Melissa made landfall on Tuesday in Jamaica as a catastrophic Category 5 storm, one of the strongest Atlantic hurricanes in history. Authorities urged people to seek shelter and stay indoors as a storm surge of up to 4 metres and wind speeds of 295 kph were expected across southern Jamaica.

items.title: In Photos: Hurricane Melissa makes landfall in Jamaica
items.standfirst: The National Hurricane Center says Jamaica should expect catastrophic damage.
items.content: The National Hurricane Center says Jamaica should expect catastrophic damage.(Image credit: Matias Delacroix)

items.title: Hurricane Melissa Has Meteorologists Terrified
items.standfirst: The storm, which is set to make landfall in Jamaica on Tuesday, has stunned meteorologists with its intensity and the speed at which it built.
items.content: The storm, which is set to make landfall in Jamaica on Tuesday, has stunned meteorologists with its intensity and the speed at which it built.

items.title: Jamaicans take shelter as Hurricane Melissa bears down as category 5 storm
items.standfirst: Landfall expected in coming hours amid warnings of catastrophic flooding, and landslidesHurricane Melissa – follow latest updates liveJamaicans have started to take shelter from Hurricane Melissa as the category 5 storm neared the coast amid warnings of catastrophic flooding, landslides and extensive infrastructure damage.The slow-moving giant, the strongest hurricane to hit Jamaica since records began in 1851, is set to make landfall early on Tuesday and to linger over the island. Continue reading...
items.content: Landfall expected in coming hours amid warnings of catastrophic flooding, and landslidesHurricane Melissa – follow latest updates liveJamaicans have started to take shelter from Hurricane Melissa as the category 5 storm neared the coast amid warnings of catastrophic flooding, landslides and extensive infrastructure damage.The slow-moving giant, the strongest hurricane to hit Jamaica since records began in 1851, is set to make landfall early on Tuesday and to linger over the island. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Hurricane Melissa made landfall in Jamaica as a Category 5 storm.
Forecasters described Melissa as potentially the island's "storm of the century."
The storm is the strongest to ever hit the Caribbean country.
Hurricane Melissa was later downgraded to a Category 4 storm.
British tourists in Jamaica described their experience during the hurricane.

clusters.title: Latest U.S. strikes on alleged drug boats kill at least 14 people, leave 1 survivor
clusters.neutral_headline: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Boats Kill 14

items.title: Latest U.S. strikes on alleged drug boats kill at least 14 people, leave 1 survivor
items.standfirst: The U.S. military struck four more alleged drug vessels on Monday, killing at least 14 people and leaving one survivor. CBS News senior national security correspondent Charlie D'Agata has the details.
items.content: The U.S. military struck four more alleged drug vessels on Monday, killing at least 14 people and leaving one survivor. CBS News senior national security correspondent Charlie D'Agata has the details.

items.title: US military kills 14 in attacks on vessels in the Pacific, according to Hegseth
items.standfirst: US says one person survived latest strikes, having killed 51 people in attacks on at least 13 vessels in recent weeksUS politics live – latest updatesThe US military killed 14 people and left one survivor in more strikes on alleged drug-trafficking boats in the eastern Pacific, the defense secretary, Pete Hegseth, said on Monday, as the Trump administration continued to expand its campaign beyond the Caribbean.The latest strikes mean the US has now attacked at least 13 vessels and brought the officially acknowledged death toll to 51 people since the campaign began at the start of September. Continue reading...
items.content: US says one person survived latest strikes, having killed 51 people in attacks on at least 13 vessels in recent weeksUS politics live – latest updatesThe US military killed 14 people and left one survivor in more strikes on alleged drug-trafficking boats in the eastern Pacific, the defense secretary, Pete Hegseth, said on Monday, as the Trump administration continued to expand its campaign beyond the Caribbean.The latest strikes mean the US has now attacked at least 13 vessels and brought the officially acknowledged death toll to 51 people since the campaign began at the start of September. Continue reading...

items.title: How Trump's strikes on "narco-terrorists" have escalated off Venezuela and beyond
items.standfirst: The Trump administration's military campaign against alleged "narco-terrorists" has now expanded beyond Venezuela, and just had its deadliest day yet. The big picture: The U.S. has now conducted at least 13 strikes and killed at least 57 people in the Caribbean Sea and eastern Pacific Ocean. But…
items.content: The Trump administration's military campaign against alleged "narco-terrorists" has now expanded beyond Venezuela, and just had its deadliest day yet. The big picture: The U.S. has now conducted at least 13 strikes and killed at least 57 people in the Caribbean Sea and eastern Pacific Ocean. But…

items.title: US launches strikes on alleged drug-running boats off Colombia, killing 14
items.standfirst: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth announced Tuesday that the U.S. military has carried out three strikes in the eastern Pacific Ocean on four boats accused of carrying drugs, killing 14 people and leaving one survivor on the deadliest single day since the Trump administration began its divisive campaign against drug trafficking in the waters off South America. FRANCE 24's Caroline Baum reports.
items.content: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth announced Tuesday that the U.S. military has carried out three strikes in the eastern Pacific Ocean on four boats accused of carrying drugs, killing 14 people and leaving one survivor on the deadliest single day since the Trump administration began its divisive campaign against drug trafficking in the waters off South America. FRANCE 24's Caroline Baum reports.

items.title: US kills 14 people in three strikes on alleged drug-smuggling boats
items.standfirst: The string of strikes in the Eastern Pacific Ocean brings the total known death toll from the US bombing campaign to 57.
items.content: The string of strikes in the Eastern Pacific Ocean brings the total known death toll from the US bombing campaign to 57.

items.title: US strikes on alleged drug-running boats in eastern Pacific kill 14
items.standfirst: The US military carried out three strikes off the coast of Colombia on Monday against suspected drug-running boats, killing 14 and leaving one survivor. The death toll from the 13 disclosed strikes since early September now stands at at least 57 people.
items.content: The US military carried out three strikes off the coast of Colombia on Monday against suspected drug-running boats, killing 14 and leaving one survivor. The death toll from the 13 disclosed strikes since early September now stands at at least 57 people.

ai_summary: The US military conducted strikes on alleged drug vessels in the Pacific.
The strikes resulted in the deaths of at least 14 people.
One person survived the latest strikes.
The US has now attacked at least 13 vessels in the campaign.
The campaign has expanded beyond Venezuela.

clusters.title: Air traffic controllers miss first full paycheck due to shutdown
clusters.neutral_headline: Air Traffic Controllers Miss Paychecks Due to Shutdown

items.title: Air traffic controllers miss first full paycheck due to shutdown
items.standfirst: The union representing air traffic controllers says its members missed their first full paychecks on Tuesday. Air traffic controllers are considered essential federal employees and must continue to work, unpaid, through the government shutdown. CBS News correspondent Tom Hanson reports.
items.content: The union representing air traffic controllers says its members missed their first full paychecks on Tuesday. Air traffic controllers are considered essential federal employees and must continue to work, unpaid, through the government shutdown. CBS News correspondent Tom Hanson reports.

items.title: Air traffic controllers receive $0 paychecks as government shutdown stretches
items.standfirst: Nearly 11,000 air traffic controllers, deemed essential workers, did not receive wages for two weeks of workAir traffic controllers and Transportation Security Administration employees have missed their first paycheck as the federal government shutdown rolls through its fourth week. They remain required to work.Nearly 11,000 air traffic controllers, who are deemed essential workers, received a $0 paycheck on Tuesday, equating to two weeks of unpaid work. Sean Duffy, the transportation secretary, warned at a Tuesday press conference that another missed paycheck could be financially catastrophic for employees. Continue reading...
items.content: Nearly 11,000 air traffic controllers, deemed essential workers, did not receive wages for two weeks of workAir traffic controllers and Transportation Security Administration employees have missed their first paycheck as the federal government shutdown rolls through its fourth week. They remain required to work.Nearly 11,000 air traffic controllers, who are deemed essential workers, received a $0 paycheck on Tuesday, equating to two weeks of unpaid work. Sean Duffy, the transportation secretary, warned at a Tuesday press conference that another missed paycheck could be financially catastrophic for employees. Continue reading...

items.title: Why Unpaid Air Traffic Controllers Are Driving Uber and DoorDash Right Now

items.content: Forbes Staff Writer Suzanne Rowan Kelleher joins Forbes Talks to discuss the fallout from the government shutdown on essential ...

items.title: Shutdown stretches into 28th day as Senate again fails to pass spending legislation
items.standfirst: As funding for food aid program is about to be exhausted, Congress fails for 13th time to advance Republican billAir traffic controllers receive $0 paychecks as government shutdown stretchesThe US government shutdown stretched into its 28th day with no resolution in sight on Tuesday, as the Senate remained deadlocked over spending legislation even as a crucial food aid program teeters on the brink of exhausting its funding.For the 13th time, Senate Democrats blocked a Republican-backed bill that would have funded federal agencies through 21 November. The minority party has refused to provide the necessary support for the bill to clear the 60-vote threshold for advancement in the Senate because it does not include funding for healthcare programs, or curbs on Donald Trump’s cuts to congressionally approved funding. Continue reading...
items.content: As funding for food aid program is about to be exhausted, Congress fails for 13th time to advance Republican billAir traffic controllers receive $0 paychecks as government shutdown stretchesThe US government shutdown stretched into its 28th day with no resolution in sight on Tuesday, as the Senate remained deadlocked over spending legislation even as a crucial food aid program teeters on the brink of exhausting its funding.For the 13th time, Senate Democrats blocked a Republican-backed bill that would have funded federal agencies through 21 November. The minority party has refused to provide the necessary support for the bill to clear the 60-vote threshold for advancement in the Senate because it does not include funding for healthcare programs, or curbs on Donald Trump’s cuts to congressionally approved funding. Continue reading...

items.title: Airlines feeding air traffic controllers as they miss first paychecks
items.standfirst: Airlines are donating meals to unpaid federal aviation workers during the government shutdown as air traffic controllers missed their first paychecks.
items.content: Airlines are donating meals to unpaid federal aviation workers during the government shutdown as air traffic controllers missed their first paychecks.

items.content: More air traffic controllers are calling in sick, often to work another job to pay for groceries and medicines.

clusters.title: At least 64 killed as police launch deadliest-ever raid ahead of COP30
clusters.neutral_headline: Rio Police Raid Kills at Least 64

items.title: At least 64 killed as police launch deadliest-ever raid ahead of COP30
items.standfirst: At least 64 people have been killed after police in Rio de Janeiro carried out a deadly raid days before the city hosts events linked to COP30.
items.content: At least 64 people have been killed after police in Rio de Janeiro carried out a deadly raid days before the city hosts events linked to COP30.

items.title: Rio de Janeiro’s Deadliest-Ever Police Raid Leaves 64 Dead
Violent police raids in Rio de Janeiro kill at least 64 people
items.standfirst: At least 64 people were killed and 81 arrested in northern Rio de Janeiro on Tuesday as police launched their biggest ever raid on the city's main drug-trafficking gang. As many as 2,500 heavily-armed officers, backed by armoured vehicles, helicopters and drones, took part in the operation.
items.content: At least 64 people were killed and 81 arrested in northern Rio de Janeiro on Tuesday as police launched their biggest ever raid on the city's main drug-trafficking gang. As many as 2,500 heavily-armed officers, backed by armoured vehicles, helicopters and drones, took part in the operation.

ai_summary: Police in Rio de Janeiro launched a deadly raid.
The raid occurred days before COP30-related events.
At least 64 people were killed in the raid.
The raid was the biggest ever conducted by police in the city.
81 people were arrested during the operation.

items.title: Dozens of states sue Trump administration over food stamp cuts
items.standfirst: Half of all U.S. states and the District of Columbia have sued the Trump administration over cutting off funding for food stamps amid the ongoing government shutdown
items.content: Half of all U.S. states and the District of Columbia have sued the Trump administration over cutting off funding for food stamps amid the ongoing government shutdown

items.title: Two dozen states sue White House over food stamps suspension amid shutdown
items.standfirst: Federal food assistance benefits for low-income families set to expire on 1 November due to government shutdownA coalition of more than two dozen states on Tuesday sued the Trump administration over its decision to suspend food stamps during the government shutdown.The lawsuit, co-led by New York, California and Massachusetts, asks a federal judge to force the US Department of Agriculture to tap into emergency reserve funds to distribute food benefits to the nearly 42 million families and children who rely on the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (Snap). The USDA has said no benefits will be issued on 1 November. Continue reading...
items.content: Federal food assistance benefits for low-income families set to expire on 1 November due to government shutdownA coalition of more than two dozen states on Tuesday sued the Trump administration over its decision to suspend food stamps during the government shutdown.The lawsuit, co-led by New York, California and Massachusetts, asks a federal judge to force the US Department of Agriculture to tap into emergency reserve funds to distribute food benefits to the nearly 42 million families and children who rely on the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (Snap). The USDA has said no benefits will be issued on 1 November. Continue reading...

items.title: 25 states sue Trump administration over food stamp freeze during shutdown
items.standfirst: Officials from half the states and the District of Columbia are asking a federal judge to order the Department of Agriculture to provide food stamp benefits for November.
items.content: Officials from half the states and the District of Columbia are asking a federal judge to order the Department of Agriculture to provide food stamp benefits for November.

items.title: Texas sues Tylenol makers over disproven claims about autism

Medical experts have resoundingly rejected assertions from the administration, particularly Health and…

Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton sued the makers of Tylenol, Johnson & Johnson and Kenvue, claiming that they deceptively marketed the over-the-counter…

items.title: Texas sues Tylenol makers, claiming they hid drug's autism risks
items.standfirst: The makers of Tylenol, Johnson & Johnson and Kenvue, were sued on Tuesday by Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton, who accused them of knowingly hiding the drug's supposed links to autism and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. Paxton, a Republican, sued five weeks after Republican President Donald Trump said using Tylenol during pregnancy can cause autism in children. Trump is not a doctor, and his claim is unproven and not backed by scientific evidence. FRANCE 24's Fraser Jackson has the details from Washington.
items.content: The makers of Tylenol, Johnson & Johnson and Kenvue, were sued on Tuesday by Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton, who accused them of knowingly hiding the drug's supposed links to autism and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. Paxton, a Republican, sued five weeks after Republican President Donald Trump said using Tylenol during pregnancy can cause autism in children. Trump is not a doctor, and his claim is unproven and not backed by scientific evidence. FRANCE 24's Fraser Jackson has the details from Washington.

items.title: Texas attorney general sues Tylenol makers over autism claims
items.standfirst: He accuses them of hiding alleged dangers from the drug, following the Trump administration's unproven claim it is linked to autism.
items.content: He accuses them of hiding alleged dangers from the drug, following the Trump administration's unproven claim it is linked to autism.

ai_summary: Texas is suing Tylenol makers over alleged autism links.
The lawsuit echoes debunked claims about autism.
The Texas Attorney General is Ken Paxton.
The lawsuit claims deceptive marketing to pregnant women.
The claims are not backed by scientific evidence.

clusters.title: Brigitte Macron's life 'deteriorated' after alleged cyber-bullying, daughter says
clusters.neutral_headline: False Claims Damaged Brigitte Macron’s Quality of Life

items.title: Brigitte Macron's life 'deteriorated' after alleged cyber-bullying, daughter says
items.standfirst: Tiphaine Auzière was testifying in the trial of ten people accused of cyber-bullying her mother, the French first lady.
items.content: Tiphaine Auzière was testifying in the trial of ten people accused of cyber-bullying her mother, the French first lady.

items.title: False claims online damaged Brigitte Macron’s quality of life, daughter tells court
items.standfirst: Tiphaine Auzière spoke at trial of 10 people accused of harassment by posting claims that French first lady was born a manBrigitte Macron’s daughter has told a Paris court that false claims online that the French first lady was born a man had damaged her mother’s quality of life, leaving her worrying every day about the clothes she wears and how she stands.Tiphaine Auzière, 41, a lawyer, was called as a witness at the trial of 10 people accused of online harassment of Brigitte Macron by creating or reposting social media posts falsely claiming she was a man. Continue reading...
items.content: Tiphaine Auzière spoke at trial of 10 people accused of harassment by posting claims that French first lady was born a manBrigitte Macron’s daughter has told a Paris court that false claims online that the French first lady was born a man had damaged her mother’s quality of life, leaving her worrying every day about the clothes she wears and how she stands.Tiphaine Auzière, 41, a lawyer, was called as a witness at the trial of 10 people accused of online harassment of Brigitte Macron by creating or reposting social media posts falsely claiming she was a man. Continue reading...

items.title: Cyberbullying led to a 'deterioration' in Brigitte Macron's health, daughter says
items.standfirst: Brigitte Macron's daughter Tiphaine Auziére told a French court on Tuesday that cyberbullying had led to a "deterioration" in the French first lady's health. Auziére spoke on the second day of the trial in Paris, where 10 people are accused of amplifying rumours that her mother was assigned male at birth. French prosecutors announced earlier that day that they are seeking suspended prison terms of three months to 12 months for the defendants.
items.content: Brigitte Macron's daughter Tiphaine Auziére told a French court on Tuesday that cyberbullying had led to a "deterioration" in the French first lady's health. Auziére spoke on the second day of the trial in Paris, where 10 people are accused of amplifying rumours that her mother was assigned male at birth. French prosecutors announced earlier that day that they are seeking suspended prison terms of three months to 12 months for the defendants.

ai_summary: Brigitte Macron's daughter testified in a cyber-bullying trial.
The trial involves ten people accused of online harassment.
False claims online damaged Brigitte Macron's quality of life.
The claims falsely stated she was born a man.
The daughter said her mother worries daily about her appearance.

clusters.title: Monkeys who escaped after truck overturned have been killed, 1 still missing

clusters.title: OpenAI Gives Long-Time Backer Microsoft 27% Stake
clusters.neutral_headline: OpenAI Gives Long-Time Backer Microsoft 27% Stake

items.title: OpenAI Gives Long-Time Backer Microsoft 27% Stake
OpenAI’s For-Profit Path Cleared | Bloomberg Tech 10/28/2025
items.standfirst: Bloomberg’s Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow discuss OpenAI’s agreement to give Microsoft a 27% stake in the startup as part of a restructuring plan that clears the path for the ChatGPT maker to become a for-profit business. Plus, the chair of Tesla’s board of directors talks about efforts to convince investors to approve the proposed $1 trillion compensation package for Elon Musk. And, Nvidia plans to make a $1 billion equity investment in Nokia, this as Nvidia’s GTC conference gets underway in DC. (Source: Bloomberg)
items.content: Bloomberg’s Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow discuss OpenAI’s agreement to give Microsoft a 27% stake in the startup as part of a restructuring plan that clears the path for the ChatGPT maker to become a for-profit business. Plus, the chair of Tesla’s board of directors talks about efforts to convince investors to approve the proposed $1 trillion compensation package for Elon Musk. And, Nvidia plans to make a $1 billion equity investment in Nokia, this as Nvidia’s GTC conference gets underway in DC. (Source: Bloomberg)

items.title: OpenAI Gives Microsoft 27% Stake, Completes For-Profit Shift
items.standfirst: OpenAI is giving its long-time backer Microsoft Corp. a 27% ownership stake as part of a restructuring plan that took nearly a year to negotiate, removing a major uncertainty for both companies and clearing the path for the ChatGPT maker to become a for-profit business.
items.content: OpenAI is giving its long-time backer Microsoft Corp. a 27% ownership stake as part of a restructuring plan that took nearly a year to negotiate, removing a major uncertainty for both companies and clearing the path for the ChatGPT maker to become a for-profit business.

ai_summary: OpenAI is giving Microsoft a 27% ownership stake.
This is part of a restructuring plan.
The plan clears the path for OpenAI to become for-profit.
The agreement took nearly a year to negotiate.
The deal removes major uncertainty for both companies.

clusters.title: Ivory Coast’s economic champion Ouattara consolidates power with fourth presidential term
clusters.neutral_headline: Ouattara Wins Fourth Term as Ivory Coast President

items.title: Ivory Coast’s economic champion Ouattara consolidates power with fourth presidential term
items.standfirst: Ivory Coast’s Alassane Ouattara was re-elected in a landslide victory on Monday for a fourth presidential term, in a vote that was marked by the lack of credible opposition. The former high-ranking civil servant, who has led the West African country since 2011, has been both lauded for his economic success and accused of being an increasingly authoritarian leader.
items.content: Ivory Coast’s Alassane Ouattara was re-elected in a landslide victory on Monday for a fourth presidential term, in a vote that was marked by the lack of credible opposition. The former high-ranking civil servant, who has led the West African country since 2011, has been both lauded for his economic success and accused of being an increasingly authoritarian leader.

items.title: Alassane Ouattara wins landslide fourth term as Ivory Coast’s president
items.standfirst: Low turnout said to have made for most peaceful election in years, as 83-year-old accused of clampdown on dissent wins 89.77% of voteAlassane Ouattara has been declared the winner of the presidential election in Ivory Coast by a landslide.According to provisional results announced by the Independent Electoral Commission (CIE) on Monday evening, the 83-year-old won a fourth term as head of the west African country with 89.77% or 3.75m votes. Continue reading...
items.content: Low turnout said to have made for most peaceful election in years, as 83-year-old accused of clampdown on dissent wins 89.77% of voteAlassane Ouattara has been declared the winner of the presidential election in Ivory Coast by a landslide.According to provisional results announced by the Independent Electoral Commission (CIE) on Monday evening, the 83-year-old won a fourth term as head of the west African country with 89.77% or 3.75m votes. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Alassane Ouattara won a fourth presidential term in Ivory Coast.
The election was marked by a lack of credible opposition.
Ouattara has led the country since 2011.
He has been lauded for economic success.
He has also been accused of being authoritarian.
